flashcards.front: What is objective 1 for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Apply power smoothly and maintain directional control ±5° heading deviation

flashcards.front: What is objective 2 for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Rotate at proper speed ±5 knots of VX or VY as appropriate

flashcards.front: What is objective 3 for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Establish and maintain VY climb ±5 knots

flashcards.front: What is objective 4 for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Maintain runway centerline ±1/2 runway width

flashcards.front: What is objective 5 for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Demonstrate proper crosswind technique for wind conditions

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Takeoff and Climb (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Smooth power application prevents swerving and engine shock cooling

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Takeoff and Climb (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Right rudder is needed to counteract left-turning tendencies (P-factor, torque, spiraling slipstream, gyroscopic precession)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Takeoff and Climb (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Rotate at proper speed - too early causes prolonged ground roll, too late risks tire/prop damage

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Takeoff and Climb (Point 4)
flashcards.back: VY provides best rate of climb - critical for obstacle clearance

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Takeoff and Climb (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Crosswind correction: Full aileron on ground, reduce as speed increases, crab after liftoff

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Takeoff and Climb (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Maintain extended runway centerline, not heading (±10°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Takeoff and Climb (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Trim for hands-off flight at VY

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Airspeed ±5 knots

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Altitude ±100 feet

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Heading ±10°

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Bank angle ±5°

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Rotation speed ±2 knots

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Climb rate ±200 fpm

flashcards.front: What is an important safety consideration for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Maintain situational awareness at all times

flashcards.front: What is an important safety consideration for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Follow all applicable regulations

flashcards.front: What is an important safety consideration for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Use proper checklists

flashcards.front: What is an important safety consideration for Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Maintain aircraft control

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Inadequate right rudder during acceleration - airplane veers left - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Premature rotation - prolonged ground roll - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Delayed rotation - tire/prop damage risk - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Inadequate crosswind correction - drift off centerline - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Fixating on instruments - not maintaining outside reference - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Insufficient power application - poor acceleration - This leads to unsafe operations and poor learning outcomes

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Poor trim usage - excessive control pressure - This leads to unsafe operations and poor learning outcomes

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Takeoff and Climb?
flashcards.back: Inadequate clearing turns - collision hazard - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness

flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Rotate at proper speed', 'acsReference': 'VII.A.2', 'tolerance': '±5 knots of VX or VY as appropriate'} to proficiency standards

flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Establish and maintain VY climb', 'acsReference': 'VII.A.3', 'tolerance': '±5 knots of VY'} within specified tolerances

flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Maintain runway centerline', 'acsReference': 'VII.A.4', 'tolerance': '±1/2 runway width'} within specified tolerances

flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Demonstrate proper crosswind technique', 'acsReference': 'VII.A.5', 'tolerance': 'Appropriate correction for wind conditions'} with precision and consistency

flashcards.front: During Ground Briefing (15 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: VY provides the best rate of climb - use it to clear obstacles quickly

flashcards.front: During Ground Briefing (15 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Maintain centerline with rudder, not ailerons

flashcards.front: During Ground Briefing (15 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Rotation speed is typically 60-70 knots for trainers

flashcards.front: During Ground Briefing (15 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Crosswind correction starts on ground roll, continues through climb

flashcards.front: During Demonstration - Normal Takeoff (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Smooth, continuous control inputs - no jerky movements

flashcards.front: During Demonstration - Normal Takeoff (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Eyes outside during takeoff - brief instrument scans only

flashcards.front: During Demonstration - Normal Takeoff (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Maintain centerline throughout roll and initial climb

flashcards.front: During Demonstration - Normal Takeoff (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Trim is essential for precise airspeed control

flashcards.front: During Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: It's normal to drift from centerline initially - prompt corrections

flashcards.front: During Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Airspeed control improves with practice - be patient

flashcards.front: During Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Positive, specific feedback: 'Good rudder input there!'

flashcards.front: During Guided Practice - Student First Attempt (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Safety first - instructor takes controls if necessary

flashcards.front: During Demonstration - Crosswind Takeoff (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Aileron deflection decreases as speed increases

flashcards.front: During Demonstration - Crosswind Takeoff (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Crab into wind immediately after liftoff

flashcards.front: During Demonstration - Crosswind Takeoff (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Never let the airplane drift - maintain extended centerline

flashcards.front: During Demonstration - Crosswind Takeoff (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Rudder controls direction, ailerons prevent drift

flashcards.front: During Student Practice with Variations (15 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: CFI candidates must both perform AND teach simultaneously

flashcards.front: During Student Practice with Variations (15 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Recognizing errors in others sharpens your own performance

flashcards.front: During Student Practice with Variations (15 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Clear, concise corrections are more effective than lengthy explanations

flashcards.front: During Debrief (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Every takeoff offers learning opportunities

flashcards.front: During Debrief (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: ACS standards require VY ±5 knots - practice to exceed minimum

flashcards.front: During Debrief (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Crosswind technique improves with exposure

flashcards.front: During Debrief (10 minutes) of Normal Takeoff and Climb, what is important?
flashcards.back: Teaching while flying requires extra mental capacity - builds with practice

flashcards.front: What is objective 1 for Normal Approach and Landing?
flashcards.back: Maintain stabilized approach ±5 knots airspeed, ±100 feet altitude

flashcards.front: What is objective 2 for Normal Approach and Landing?
flashcards.back: Touch down in touchdown zone (first 1/3 of runway)

flashcards.front: What is objective 3 for Normal Approach and Landing?
flashcards.back: Maintain runway centerline ±1/2 runway width

flashcards.front: What is objective 4 for Normal Approach and Landing?
flashcards.back: Demonstrate proper crosswind technique for wind conditions

flashcards.front: What is objective 5 for Normal Approach and Landing?
flashcards.back: Execute go-around if necessary before touchdown

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Approach and Landing (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Stabilized approach = consistent landings (on speed, on glide path, configured, aligned)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Approach and Landing (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Pitch for airspeed, power for descent rate - primary/secondary effects (±10 knots)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Approach and Landing (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Aim point shouldn't move in windscreen - if rising, too low; if falling, too high

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Approach and Landing (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Flare begins 10-20 feet AGL and is progressive - not one motion

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Approach and Landing (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Roundout → Hold off → Touchdown in three distinct phases

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Approach and Landing (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Crosswind: Crab on approach, transition to wing-low before touchdown

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Approach and Landing (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Go-around decision must be made before touchdown - never force a bad landing

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Normal Approach and Landing (Point 8)
flashcards.back: After touchdown: Fly the airplane until it's parked and secured

flashcards.back: Airspeed ±5 knots

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Normal Approach and Landing?

flashcards.back: Use proper checklists

flashcards.back: Maintain aircraft control

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Approach and Landing?
flashcards.back: Unstabilized approach - varying airspeeds and descent rates - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.back: High approach - difficulty in landing in touchdown zone - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.back: Low approach - risk of undershooting runway - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.back: Fast approach - floating and long landing - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.back: Slow approach - stall risk and hard landing - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.back: Inadequate crosswind correction - drift off centerline - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Normal Approach and Landing?
flashcards.back: Delayed go-around decision - unsafe landing - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is objective 1 for Steep Turns?
flashcards.back: Establish and maintain 45° bank angle ±5° within 3 seconds of entry

flashcards.front: What is objective 2 for Steep Turns?
flashcards.back: Maintain altitude ±100 feet throughout turn with maximum 50 feet loss during entry/recovery

flashcards.front: What is objective 3 for Steep Turns?
flashcards.back: Maintain airspeed ±10 knots with power adjustment of 100-200 RPM above cruise

flashcards.front: What is objective 4 for Steep Turns?
flashcards.back: Roll out on entry heading ±10° leading rollout by 22-23°

flashcards.front: What is objective 5 for Steep Turns?
flashcards.back: Perform both left and right steep turns with consistent technique

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Steep Turns (Point 1)
flashcards.back: 45° bank angle ±5° required - establish within 3 seconds of entry (±5°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Steep Turns (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Altitude control requires increased back pressure - maintain ±100 feet throughout (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Steep Turns (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Power increase (100-200 RPM) needed to maintain airspeed - adjust simultaneously with bank entry (±10 knots)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Steep Turns (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Load factor increases to 1.4 G at 45° bank - affects stall speed and structural limits (±5°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Steep Turns (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Stall speed increases by 20% - critical awareness for safety

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Steep Turns (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Lead rollout by 22-23° to avoid overshooting - half the bank angle (±5°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Steep Turns (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Clearing turns before entry required - 90° minimum

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Steep Turns (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Constant visual scan prevents spatial disorientation - outside reference essential

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight-and-Level Flight (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Straight-and-level is foundation of all instrument and flight training

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight-and-Level Flight (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Pitch primarily controls altitude (secondary: airspeed) (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight-and-Level Flight (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Power primarily controls airspeed (secondary: altitude) (±100 feet)

flashcards.back: Trim eliminates control pressures - mandatory for precision

flashcards.back: Visual attitude is primary reference, instruments confirm

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Principles of Flight (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Load factor increases in turns - affects stall speed and structural limits

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Human Factors (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Human factors: How human capabilities and limitations affect flight safety

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Human Factors (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM): Structured approach to decisions

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Human Factors (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Five hazardous attitudes: Anti-authority, Impulsivity, Invulnerability, Macho, Resignation

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Human Factors (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Each hazardous attitude has antidote thought pattern

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Human Factors (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Stress management: Recognize and mitigate physical/psychological stress

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Human Factors (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Workload management: Prioritize tasks during high-workload situations

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Human Factors (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Situational awareness: Maintaining accurate perception of factors affecting flight

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Human Factors (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Automation management: Using and managing automated systems appropriately

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Visual scanning essential for collision avoidance

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Most midair collisions occur during daylight, clear weather, near airports

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance (Point 3)
flashcards.back: See and avoid is pilot's primary responsibility

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Empty-field myopia: Eyes relax to 10-30 feet when no objects to focus on

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Effective scan: Divide sky into sectors, focus on each sector 1-2 seconds

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Peripheral vision detects motion - direct vision identifies objects

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Relative motion indicates collision course - object not moving in windscreen

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Clearing turns before maneuvers, climbs, descents critical

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Not scanning outside cockpit - fixation on instruments - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Inadequate clearing before maneuvers - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Scanning too quickly without focusing on sectors - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Not accounting for blind spots caused by aircraft structure - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Assuming ATC or technology will prevent collision - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Not looking for traffic in traffic pattern - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Failure to make radio position reports - This can result in loss of aircraft control

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Not seeing traffic that ATC has pointed out - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Staring at one spot (empty-field myopia) - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Visual Scanning and Collision Avoidance?
flashcards.back: Not adjusting scan for different phases of flight - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Runway Incursion Avoidance (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Runway incursion: Unauthorized aircraft/vehicle/person on runway

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Runway Incursion Avoidance (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Leading cause: Pilot deviations during taxi operations

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Runway Incursion Avoidance (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Read back all runway crossing/hold short clearances

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Runway Incursion Avoidance (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Never cross hold short line without explicit clearance

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Runway Incursion Avoidance (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Airport signs: Red = stop, yellow = caution, black on yellow = location

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Runway Incursion Avoidance (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Airport markings: Yellow taxi lines, runway hold short markings

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Runway Incursion Avoidance (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Enhanced taxiway centerline marking at high-risk intersections

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Runway Incursion Avoidance (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Write down taxi instructions (or have copilot/CFI write them)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Performance and Limitations (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Performance: How aircraft performs under various conditions

flashcards.back: Limitations: Operating limits that must not be exceeded

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Performance and Limitations (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Weight limits: Max gross, max landing, max ramp, max zero fuel

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Performance and Limitations (Point 8)
flashcards.back: CG limits: Forward and aft limits for safe flight

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for National Airspace System (Point 1)
flashcards.back: National Airspace System: Complex system of airspace classifications

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for National Airspace System (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Class A: 18,000 MSL to FL600, IFR only, clearance required

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for National Airspace System (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Class B: Busy airports, surface to 10,000 MSL, clearance required, Mode C

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for National Airspace System (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Class C: Medium airports, surface to 4,000 AGL, two-way radio, Mode C

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for National Airspace System (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Class D: Towered airports, surface to 2,500 AGL, two-way radio required

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for National Airspace System (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Class E: Controlled airspace not A/B/C/D, IFR traffic control

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for National Airspace System (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Class G: Uncontrolled airspace, pilot responsible for separation

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for National Airspace System (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Special Use Airspace: Prohibited, Restricted, Warning, MOA, Alert

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation Systems and Radar Services (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Navigation systems: VOR, DME, GPS, ADF (legacy), ILS

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation Systems and Radar Services (Point 2)
flashcards.back: VOR: VHF Omnidirectional Range - radials from station

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation Systems and Radar Services (Point 3)
flashcards.back: GPS: Global Positioning System - satellite navigation, WAAS enhanced

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation Systems and Radar Services (Point 4)
flashcards.back: DME: Distance Measuring Equipment - slant range distance

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation Systems and Radar Services (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Radar services: Flight Following, vectors, traffic advisories

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation Systems and Radar Services (Point 6)
flashcards.back: ATC radar: Primary (skin paint) and Secondary (transponder)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation Systems and Radar Services (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Mode C: Reports altitude, Mode S: Enhanced, ADS-B: Future (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation Systems and Radar Services (Point 8)
flashcards.back: RNAV: Area Navigation using GPS waypoints

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Navigation: Process of determining position and direction to destination

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Pilotage: Navigation by reference to visible landmarks

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Dead reckoning: Computing position by course, speed, time, wind

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning (Point 4)
flashcards.back: VOR navigation: Using VHF Omnidirectional Range for position/course

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning (Point 5)
flashcards.back: GPS navigation: Satellite-based positioning - primary nav tool today

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Flight planning: Route, altitude, fuel, weather, alternates (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Checkpoints: Visible landmarks used to verify position

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Diversion: Changing destination en route - requires new plan

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning?
flashcards.back: Inadequate flight planning before departure - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning?
flashcards.back: Not monitoring position continuously - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning?
flashcards.back: Over-reliance on GPS without backup navigation - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning?
flashcards.back: Failure to identify checkpoints - This can result in loss of aircraft control

flashcards.back: Not adjusting for winds - drifting off course - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning?
flashcards.back: Running low on fuel due to poor planning - This leads to unsafe operations and poor learning outcomes

flashcards.back: Not having alternate airport planned - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning?
flashcards.back: Getting lost and not admitting it - continuing blindly - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.back: Not using all available navigation resources - This affects safety and performance

flashcards.front: What is a common error in Navigation and Cross-Country Flight Planning?
flashcards.back: Inadequate knowledge of airspace along route - This compromises safety and learning effectiveness

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for 14 CFR and Publications (Point 1)

flashcards.back: 14 CFR Part 91: General operating and flight rules

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for 14 CFR and Publications (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Right-of-way rules: Distress has right of way, then specific priorities

flashcards.back: Hypoxia: Insufficient oxygen to body tissues

flashcards.back: Symptoms: Euphoria, impaired judgment, cyanosis, unconsciousness

flashcards.back: Time of Useful Consciousness: Varies with altitude (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for High Altitude Operations - Supplemental Oxygen (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Pulse oximeter: Measures blood oxygen saturation

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for High Altitude Operations - Pressurization (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Pressurization: Maintains cabin altitude lower than actual altitude (±100 feet)

flashcards.back: Outflow valve: Controls cabin pressure

flashcards.back: Pressurization failures: Recognize and respond appropriately

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Starting (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Engine starting: Checklist discipline critical

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Starting (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Before start: Brakes set, area clear, beacon on

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Starting (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Prime: Correct amount - too little won't start, too much floods

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Starting (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Mixture: Full rich for start (some exceptions)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Starting (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Throttle: Cracked open 1/4 inch typically

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Starting (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Ignition: Follow POH - both, left, right, or start sequence

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Starting (Point 7)
flashcards.back: After start: Oil pressure within 30 seconds (or per POH)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Starting (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Hot start: Different procedure than cold start

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Engine Starting?
flashcards.back: VMC demonstration ±2 knots

flashcards.back: Altitude ±100 feet

flashcards.back: Airspeed ±10 knots

flashcards.back: Heading ±10°

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Engine Starting?
flashcards.back: Rudder deflection ±5°

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Engine Starting?
flashcards.back: Engine failure response ±3 seconds

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing, Airport Signs, and Lighting (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Taxiing: Ground operation to/from runway

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing, Airport Signs, and Lighting (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Taxi speed: Brisk walk pace, must be able to stop immediately

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing, Airport Signs, and Lighting (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Airport signs: Red = mandatory (hold short), Yellow = location/direction

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing, Airport Signs, and Lighting (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Airport markings: Yellow lines guide taxi route

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing, Airport Signs, and Lighting (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Hold short: NEVER cross without ATC clearance at towered airport

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing, Airport Signs, and Lighting (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Sterile cockpit: Minimize distractions during taxi

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing, Airport Signs, and Lighting (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Wind correction: Aileron into wind, elevator as needed

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing, Airport Signs, and Lighting (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Brake check: Verify brakes work during initial taxi

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing and Sailing (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Taxiing and sailing: Seaplane-specific water taxi operations

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing and Sailing (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Sailing: Using wind to move on water without power

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing and Sailing (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Step taxi: On step for faster water taxi

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing and Sailing (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Idle taxi: Off step, displacement mode

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing and Sailing (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Wind weathervaning: Seaplane turns into wind naturally

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing and Sailing (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Water rudders: Retractable, used for steering at slow speed

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing and Sailing (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Docking: Approach into wind when possible

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Taxiing and Sailing (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Ramping: Beaching seaplane on shore or ramp

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Before Takeoff Check (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Before takeoff check: Final verification before flight

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Before Takeoff Check (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Run-up: Check engine, mags, systems at higher RPM

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Before Takeoff Check (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Magnetos: Check both mags individually - RPM drop within limits

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Before Takeoff Check (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Carburetor heat: Check for RPM drop (confirms system works)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Before Takeoff Check (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Flight controls: Full and free movement, correct sense

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Before Takeoff Check (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Instruments: Set, checked, proper indications

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Before Takeoff Check (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Takeoff briefing: Review takeoff plan, emergency procedures

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Before Takeoff Check (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Checklist: Use checklist, don't rely on memory

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Takeoff and Climb (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Glassy water: Mirror-like surface with no visual references

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Takeoff and Climb (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Depth perception extremely difficult

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Takeoff and Climb (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Cannot judge height above water accurately

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Takeoff and Climb (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Technique: Establish descent at constant rate, wait for touchdown

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Takeoff and Climb (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Power controls descent rate precisely

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Takeoff and Climb (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Do not flare - will balloon with no references

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Takeoff and Climb (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Higher-than-normal touchdown speed acceptable

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Takeoff and Climb (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Be patient - let airplane settle to water

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Approach and Landing (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Glassy water landing: Approach with power at constant rate

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Approach and Landing (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Establish stabilized approach - power and pitch constant

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Approach and Landing (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Typical: 300-500 fpm descent rate, approach speed +5 knots

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Approach and Landing (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Do not attempt to flare - no visual references

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Approach and Landing (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Hold attitude constant, wait for water contact

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Approach and Landing (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Touchdown will be firm - acceptable on glassy water

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Approach and Landing (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Power on throughout - controlled descent to surface

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Glassy Water Approach and Landing (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Patience essential - rushing causes errors

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Slip to a Landing (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Forward slip: bank and opposite rudder to steepen descent (±5°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Slip to a Landing (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Sideslip: maintains longitudinal axis alignment (crosswind)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Slip to a Landing (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Slip increases drag - steep descent without airspeed increase (±10 knots)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Slip to a Landing (Point 4)
flashcards.back: More aggressive slip = steeper descent

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Slip to a Landing (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Recovery: neutralize controls to coordinated flight

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Slip to a Landing (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Must recover before landing - land coordinated

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Slip to a Landing (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Check POH: some aircraft prohibit slips with flaps extended

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Slip to a Landing (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Slips useful when: too high, no/limited flaps, crosswind correction

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight Climbs and Climbing Turns (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Straight climb: Add power, raise pitch for VY, trim off pressures

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight Climbs and Climbing Turns (Point 2)
flashcards.back: VY provides best rate of climb - fastest way to gain altitude (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight Climbs and Climbing Turns (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Pitch controls airspeed during climb, power controls rate (±10 knots)

flashcards.back: Trim essential for consistent climb performance

flashcards.back: Climbing turns increase load factor - need extra back pressure

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight Climbs and Climbing Turns (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Bank angle in climbing turn typically 15-20° maximum (±5°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight Climbs and Climbing Turns (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Steeper bank requires significantly more back pressure (±5°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight Climbs and Climbing Turns (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Maintain VY ±5 knots throughout climb and turns

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Straight Descents and Descending Turns (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Power primarily controls descent rate (less power = faster descent)

flashcards.back: Pitch primarily controls descent airspeed (±10 knots)

flashcards.back: Roll out on entry heading ±10° - precise heading control (±10°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Steep Spiral (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Altitude gain typically 200-400 feet - depends on aircraft and technique (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Accelerated Stalls (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Accelerated stall: Occurs at higher airspeed due to increased load factor (±10 knots)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Accelerated Stalls (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Caused by abrupt control inputs or high-G maneuvers

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Accelerated Stalls (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Can occur at any airspeed if load factor exceeds limit (±10 knots)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Accelerated Stalls (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Entry: Establish airspeed at or below VA (maneuvering speed) (±10 knots)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Accelerated Stalls (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Smoothly roll to 45° bank, apply back pressure (±5°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Accelerated Stalls (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Stall break will be abrupt - immediate recovery essential

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Accelerated Stalls (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Recovery at FIRST indication of stall (not full stall)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Accelerated Stalls (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Reduce back pressure, level wings, recover

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for Accelerated Stalls?
flashcards.back: Stall recognition ±2 knots

flashcards.back: Recovery altitude ±100 feet

flashcards.back: Recovery time ±3 seconds

flashcards.back: Airspeed ±5 knots

flashcards.back: AOA ±2°

flashcards.back: Buffet onset ±1 knot

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Cross-Controlled Stall Demonstration (Point 1)

flashcards.back: Demonstration only - do not have student perform

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Cross-Controlled Stall Demonstration (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Scenario: Overshooting final, pilot uses rudder to turn without bank (±5°)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Cross-Controlled Stall Demonstration (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Setup: Slowing flight, power off, turning configuration

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Cross-Controlled Stall Demonstration (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Cross-control: Top rudder, opposite aileron (skidding turn)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Cross-Controlled Stall Demonstration (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Result: Rapid, uncontrolled roll toward low wing

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Cross-Controlled Stall Demonstration (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Most dangerous during base-to-final turn

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Cross-Controlled Stall Demonstration (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Recovery may be difficult or impossible at low altitude (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Elevator Trim Stall Demonstration (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Elevator trim stall: Stall from improper trim during go-around

flashcards.back: Setup: Landing configuration, approach speed, trim nose-up

flashcards.back: If pilot doesn't push forward: Stall results from excessive pitch

flashcards.back: Real scenario: Student doesn't push forward during go-around

flashcards.back: Pitch adjustment controls airspeed (±10 knots)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Constant Airspeed Descents (Point 8)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Unusual attitudes: Unintentional airplane attitude

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Nose-high: Decreasing airspeed, increasing altitude or VSI up (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Nose-low: Increasing airspeed, decreasing altitude or VSI down (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Nose-high recovery: Power idle, pitch down, level wings, recover

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Nose-low recovery: Power idle if needed, level wings, gentle pull

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Never pull before leveling wings - can worsen situation

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Scan multiple instruments - don't trust just one

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Recovery from Unusual Flight Attitudes (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Causes: Spatial disorientation, distraction, autopilot disconnect

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated) (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Engine failure after liftoff: Critical emergency requiring immediate action

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated) (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Maintain directional control: Most important initial action

flashcards.back: Verify failed engine: Dead foot, dead engine

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated) (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Fly the airplane: Don't let it stall or spin

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated) (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Decision: Enough runway to land ahead? If yes, land. If no, continue.

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated) (Point 6)
flashcards.back: Feather failed engine: Reduce drag

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated) (Point 7)
flashcards.back: Climb at VYSE (blue line): Best single-engine climb speed

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated) (Point 8)
flashcards.back: Single-engine service ceiling: May not be able to maintain altitude (±100 feet)

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'The applicant demonstrates and simultaneously explains how to: Promptly recognize an engine failure, maintain control, and use appropriate emergency procedures.', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S1'} with precision and consistency

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Establish VYSE; if obstructions are present, establish best single-engine angle of climb speed (VXSE) or VMC +5 knots, whichever is greater, until obstructions are cleared. Then transition to VYSE.', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S2'} to proficiency standards

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Reduce drag by retracting landing gear and flaps in accordance with the manufacturer’s guidance.', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S3'} to proficiency standards

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Simulate feathering the propeller on the inoperative engine (evaluator should then establish zero thrust on the inoperative engine).', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S4'} to proficiency standards

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Use flight controls in the proper combination as recommended by the manufacturer, or as required to maintain best performance, and trim as required.', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S5'} within specified tolerances

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Monitor the operating engine and aircraft systems and make adjustments as necessary.', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S6'} to proficiency standards

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Recognize the airplane’s performance capabilities. If a climb is not possible at VYSE, maintain VYSE and return to the departure airport for landing, or initiate an approach to the most suitable landing area available.', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S7'} within specified tolerances

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Simulate securing the inoperative engine.', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S8'} to proficiency standards

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Maintain heading ±10° and airspeed ±5 knots.', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S9', 'tolerance': '±10°'} within specified tolerances

flashcards.front: What is a completion standard for Engine Failure After Liftoff (Simulated)?
flashcards.back: {'standard': 'Complete the appropriate checklist(s).', 'acsReference': 'AI.XII.F.S10'} to proficiency standards

flashcards.front: What is objective 1 for After Landing, Parking, and Securing?
flashcards.back: Demonstrate proper night lighting with adequate lighting for safety

flashcards.front: What is objective 2 for After Landing, Parking, and Securing?
flashcards.back: Demonstrate proper night vision with red light preservation

flashcards.front: What is objective 3 for After Landing, Parking, and Securing?
flashcards.back: Demonstrate proper night procedures with standard night procedures

flashcards.front: What is objective 4 for After Landing, Parking, and Securing?
flashcards.back: Maintain altitude ±100 feet during flight

flashcards.front: What is objective 5 for After Landing, Parking, and Securing?
flashcards.back: Demonstrate proper emergency procedures with immediate response

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for After Landing, Parking, and Securing (Point 1)
flashcards.back: Runway/approach lighting: VASI, PAPI help judge glidepath

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for After Landing, Parking, and Securing (Point 2)
flashcards.back: Night currency: 3 T/O and landings to full stop in preceding 90 days

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for After Landing, Parking, and Securing (Point 3)
flashcards.back: Flashlight: Red preserves night vision better than white

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for After Landing, Parking, and Securing (Point 4)
flashcards.back: Emergency procedures more challenging at night

flashcards.front: Explain a key teaching point for After Landing, Parking, and Securing (Point 5)
flashcards.back: Night weather can be difficult to assess - use reports

flashcards.back: Heading ±10°

flashcards.back: Shutdown procedure ±30 seconds

flashcards.back: Securing checklist ±5 minutes

flashcards.front: What is the performance tolerance for After Landing, Parking, and Securing?
